What's going on in NK? (my thoughts) In the last 40 years, NK has launched around 140 missiles. 

Last week, NK has claimed that it successfully tested a new hypersonic missile,  labeling it a "strategic weapon", suggesting that it has nuclear capabilities. It also uses a technology that enables it to be pre-fueled & launch-ready for years. 

What is a hypersonic missile?
"Hypersonic missiles are much faster and more agile than normal ones, making them much harder for missile defence systems to intercept."
Only few other countries - China, Russia, the US and India- have the technological know-how.  Although the precise capabilities of the launched missile is hard to assess - South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff said they believed this hypersonic missile was still at an early stage of development and it will take a considerable period of time before it can be deployed in combat.-, it could "presumably present a very different challenge for missile defence from traditional ballistic missiles."  In order to see what's coming next, I believe it's necessary to take a step back to understand why does NK continue developing its weapons despite decade of sanctions. Some relevant factors are:
1) To keep of with its neighbors 
For example, recently SK tested its first submarine-launched ballistic missile, claiming it to be needed as deterrence against North Korea's "provocations". NK has repeatedly accused SK of double standards over military activities.
And concerning the nuclear power, although SK doesn't have it, its ally - the US- has couple of thousands of nuclear warheads.  2) To rally the people - especially when times are tough.
I think this is most important for the moment. It's said that economic situation is especially dire nowadays because of the Covid, and reduction of supplies from China.  What's their long-term plan? I have no clues. As far as the question, I think NK wants to establish its power and show that sanctions are irrelevant as far as it goes to advancing their "defence" systems. In fact, the busy month of September - during which NK launched 3 missiles - could be a response to the joint military exercise in August between SK and the US.
https://www.reuters.com/world/skorea-us-begin-joint-military-drills-monday-yonhap-2021-08-15/

https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/12C07/production/_101970867_north_korea_missiles_640v2_nc.png The council considers ballistic missiles to be more threatening than cruise missiles because they can carry bigger and more powerful payloads, have a much longer range, and can fly faster. A ballistic missile is powered by a rocket and follows an arc-like trajectory, while a cruise missile is powered by a jet engine and flies at a lower height.  "The development of a long-range cruise missile could pose additional challenges for South Korea's missile defences. A cruise missile doesn't have to follow a straight trajectory. Its flight plan may be programmed to avoid defences or use terrain to reduce detection, but we still don't know exactly how the North Korean version navigates."
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-58540915  Ballistic missiles are classed according to how far they can travel, the furthest of which being an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM).
North Korea has in the past tested ICBMs said to be capable of reaching nearly all of Western Europe and about half of the US mainland.

Previous famine times in NK have been quiet times when it came to extreme provocations, looking at the Wikipedia timelines. The more food aid they get, the less likely they are to do these tests. It's going to be a long winter this year for the North Korean people unfortunately. Although to me it seems like the NK government might try to do these tests at some point in order to get some sanctions relief (maybe next year?), at least for now it seems like the NKs are just so internally-focused -- not only with this famine, but with COVID. There also have been stories popping up here and there about Kim continuing to consolidate his power against the different factions in his government. I expect that things should remain quiet for the rest of the year.  I agree with crowd's 1% on nuclear tests, but the 9% on ICBM seems a bit high with only a few months remaining

As someone who's interested in Geopolitics, but a novice on North Korea- let me list my priors, based on some basic reading  - Over the years, NK's nuclear program, once they became a nuclear power- seems to have had two goals ; Increase the destructive power or yield (note their claims of building an hydrogen bomb) and miniaturize their weapons so that they can be mounted on a missile. The objective of building an ICBM is obviously linked to their latter goal and of course gaining an ability to target US. -  In Sep of 2017, it seems credible that NK tested a thermo-nuclear weapon ~ 250 KT yield, so that potentially means the former goal is met. Which brings us to next goal- miniaturization. The only way to test this is by missile launches of all kinds - in this context, I must thank @smingers for the excellent resource on the missile test
database https://www.nti.org/analysis/articles/cns-north-korea-missile-test-database/ - Now it seems  reasonable to me, given the argument I made above, the likelihood of (any) missile launch > likelihood of nuclear test. If we were to count from 2006, we have about 140 missile tests of all kinds (including successes and failures). Rounding off, that means ~ 10 tests/year. In fact, we already had one in Mar-21. Of these, 3 were ICBM and 6 were Space launch vehicles. But it's important to point out about 6 of them, came since 2012 and the last of them were in 2017 (possibly playing chicken with TrumP). Does it imply an annual base rate between 2/3 and 1? - Most NK experts believe that NK is a strategic player, using nuclear power as a bargaining chip. It seems that Covid may not had a direct, but an indirect (and devastating impact) due to impact on trade. Or more succinctly, dramatic drop in trading monies with its partners that don't care about US sanctions. Which means the US sanctions must hurt more than usual.What would be the game theoretic optimal strategy for Kim? I think, China as another strategic player in this "game", complicates matters considerably.  Although I can imagine exceptions, a worse US-China relationship should probably make NK more hostile. And symbolic hostility has been the only negotiating tool NK has used over the years (or it seems).  -Given all this, with six months to go, I would estimate an even chance for something to happen- in other words, 50% for No. And as discussed before, it's far more likely to launch an ICBM or a space vehicle than a nuclear test. So I would spilt roughly 10% for nuclear and the rest for ICBM.

Let's first look at the historical data from North Korea. We should look at the historical data to set initial probabilities, but there are a lot of idiosyncrasies about North Korea that are not present with other nuclear states, and their situation is quite unique, so I do not think using "typical nuclear state" data makes sense. We first analyze the probability of detonating a nuclear device. North Korea has detonated 6 devices in the past 15 years that they have had the ability to test a nuclear weapon, leading to a base rate of 6/15 = 0.4. However this has occurred more in recent years as they have gotten more aggressive and admittedly capable in their nuclear powers, in particular in the Obama administration vs the Trump administration. So I think using the base rate of 5 tests in the 8 years of the Obama administration is more accurate, as corroborated in my previous response. This gives a rate of about 60% for detonating a nuclear device every year. There is only half a year until Jan 1 2022, so a chance of 30% for a nuclear test before Jan 1 2022. We can also look at the historical data for ICBMs from North Korea. North Korea first had capabilities for an ICBM in 2017 and conducted 3 launches in 2017 and none since. Note this year was just before Trump with a different foreign policy focused on appeasement and denuclearization took power. There is not any more historical data on ICBMs and North Korea seems to conduct many nuclear tests every year except 2020, including one earlier this year in 2021. So given how North Korea's attitudes should match theirs in 2017 as per my previous post, I would in fact argue that there is a very high chance of an ICBM launch, maybe even 60% for the year (based on the many ICBM launches in 2017, but the lack of launches in subsequent years, and the increased similarity politically of 2017 and 2021). There is only half a year until Jan 1 2022, so a chance of 30% for an ICBM launch before Jan 1 2022.  As noted in my previous post, the historical data seems to suggest that North Korea's ICBM launches and nuclear detonations occur together. Historically it seems that neither occur in around 60% of years based on a historical data. Moreover there are more nuclear denotations than ICBM launches. So I would say 25% chance of both, a 10% chance for only a nuclear detonation, a 5% chance of launching an ICBM only, and a 60% chance of neither.

It is fair to say that North Korea's aggressiveness with respect to their nuclear program will more closely resemble their relations in the Obama administration now than in the Trump administration, considering Trump was focused on appeasement and denuclearization (https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/21/biden-rejects-trumps-approach-to-north-korea.html) -- Trump took several steps onto North Korean soil, becoming the first American president to do so". This is an approach Biden is sharply rejecting as indicated by this article, with Biden refusing to grant North Korea international recognition. In contrast, while Obama did not take an explicitly aggressive approach, he still refused to grant North Korea legitimacy and held America's position, similarly to Biden: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/world/asia/trump-north-korea-threat.html. With this in mind it is reasonable to assume that relations would pick up through 2021, the first year of the Biden administration, similarly to in 2017; this also seems logical considering Biden and Obama are of closer political background than towards Trump. At the twilight years of the Obama administration in 2016 and 2017, North Korea conducted many nuclear tests and a few ICBM launches, documented at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nuclear_weapons_tests_of_North_Korea, https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/25/world/asia/north-korea-ballistic-missiles.html, and https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-54500550. So it is reasonable to assume that North Korea will take an aggressive nuclear stance, which is further corroborated by https://www.npr.org/2021/05/02/992874499/north-korea-warns-u-s-over-bidens-big-blunder. However such nuclear tests only occur a few times a year at most in 2016-2017  and ICBM launches are similarly rare, as noted by the previous sources. Such an action would be unwise for North Korea from many perspectives, such as economic, political, etc., as indicated by Biden's aggressive stance. We can see that in 2017 and before North Korea conducted several nuclear tests, and that the ICBM launches then occurred, from the previous sources; it is unlikely that the ICBM launch would occur without the nuclear test according to the historical trend. This logic leads to my answer noted above; the largest single chance is that neither event will occur (say 50% probability), then the next most likely event is that both will if a pattern similar to 2017 plays out (say 30% probability), and then the only remaining larger chance outcome is that North Korea only conducts a nuclear test (say 15% probability).

North Korea does not have many positive international relations so an attack on another country would likely lead to retaliation from multiple countries. If they were to detonate a nuclear device, they would violate the nuclear peace treaty which would have a massive backlash, which makes this highly improbable.

North Korea has been dealing with reduced imports and support from China since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic. At the same time, the North Korean government believes that its missile and nuclear programs are key components of its foreign diplomacy. This means that even if investing in missile/nuclear programs will divert much-needed resources away from civilians, the North Korean government will very likely pursue weapons development to further disrupt US-China relations and potentially initiate sanction-relief talks with the United States. A quick sweep of reported North Korean tests also reveal an interesting pattern - a ramp up of activity in July/August (2017, 2019) and also alternating years between increased and decreased testing. Following these patterns, if North Korea was to detonate a nuclear weapon or launch an ICBM, it would likely to be sometime between July and August. There is not guarantee that the alternating years of activity will continue (especially since these years of inactivity correspond to changes in policy and relations).  From the perspective of the United States, the North Korean nuclear/missile problem may also not be their top priority. Namely, they may be most concerned about renegotiating the Iran nuclear deal. This means that North Korea may proceed with its testing. As of today, I think the probability of North Korea launching/testing a ICBM in the following months is quite high (i.e., 60%). The probability that it is also a nuclear test is probably a bit lower (10%). The probability of a solely a nuclear test is also lower because the threat that an ICBM poses to the US may make it more of a priority (5%). This leaves a 25% probability that neither will occur. If no activity occurs in the next two months, however, then all these estimates except for no activity can be downgraded.

Note that a detonation of a nuclear device can happen as a nuclear test, and not necessarily as a direct act of war - likewise with ICBMs. North Korea has conducted nuclear and ICBM tests before - 6 and ~119, respectively, according to Wikipedia. The last nuclear and ICBM tests were in 2017, with the potential range of the missile being 10000+km. Thus the occurrence of another test is not unconceivable in the next year. However, it seems unlikely that tensions with the Biden administration will escalate to this degree within the next 6 months, given the perceived inactivity during the last administration and the world's focus on the current COVID pandemic situation.

There is not much reason to detonate a nuclear weapon since we already know they have them, and there may be more severe repercussions for it than just a missile launch. North Korea has a history of launching ICBMs to demonstrate their capabilities, so there may be a launch. However there has not been a very long range missile launch in years.

P(NK nuclear & long range ICBM) = P(NK ICBM | nuclear detonation) * P(nuclear detonation)
P(NK long range ICBM | nuclear detonation) = 20%. That is, given that NK will detonate a nuclear device, it will do so via long-range ICBM with a probability of 0.20. In the unlikely event that NK does not simply conduct a nuclear test and attacks another country, the two most likely targets are its neighboring Asian countries or the US. I believe it is more likely to attack its Asian neighbors (and thus, be short range) due to history, politics, and technological considerations.
So, P(NK nuclear & long range ICBM) = .2 * .025 = .5%
P(NK long range ICBM) = 10% because NK has long-range rockets (>10,000 km) but all such missiles are still “In Development” (https://missilethreat.csis.org/country/dprk/). This probability reflects the fact that NK may increase its development of nuclear weapons technology in light of the growing obsolescence of its military capabilities. NK may want to use such a launch as a scare tactic or as a test. On the other hand, launches are extremely expensive and could draw economic sanctions.
P(none) = 1 – P(NK ICBM) – P(nuclear detonation) + P(both) = 1 - .025 - .10  + .005 = 87%

Detonating a nuclear device seems unlikely, due to the fact that the North Koreans have already verified that they have nuclear weapon capability, so testing would be unnecessary, and actually launching it would cause a response, either from the U.S. or other countries, that would prove detrimental to North Korea. Thus, the only feasible option, in my opinion, would be launching an ICBM. Given talks with Biden have not been going well, they might launch one in order to showcase their military power, but the likelihood still seems low to me given their tendency to turtle, and the lack of a need to show off to other countries to acknowledge their nuclear power since they already have.

Clips from Swig article:
'Fred Plan, senior analyst of cyber espionage at Mandiant Intelligence, told The Daily Swig that North Korean threat actors differ from other comparably sophisticated groups by being more reckless.
“One of the things that makes North Korean actors relatively more dangerous than operations from other countries is that the Pyongyang regime is isolated and disconnected from global economic trade and diplomatic engagement,” Plan explained.
“As a result, North Korea isn’t as incentivized to ‘play by the rules’ and the country continues to step over boundaries that define the acceptable behaviors of other nation-states.
“This is a key factor as to why only North Korean groups carry out state-sponsored cybercrime, such as digital bank heists, and are relatively more likely to deploy destructive wiper malware,” Plan concluded.' 'North Korean actors are constantly evolving their techniques, especially their evasion and persistence mechanisms, in order to evade detection by security products.
Hossein Jazi, a threat intelligence analyst at cybersecurity company Malwarebytes, commented: “Extensive use of packers, employing steganography to embed their malicious payload within images, erasing footprints from the device at run time, or constantly changing the encryption keys/algorithms (even within an hour of being detected), performing fileless attacks are examples of such anti-detection techniques used by these actors.”
Paul Prudhomme, head of threat intelligence advisory at IntSights, told The Daily Swig that North Korean attackers were making a greater effort to fly under the radar.'
“North Korean attacks have evolved since the beginning of diplomatic reconciliation with the US in 2018,” Prudhomme explained.
“Previous North Korean attacks were often disruptive and ‘noisy’ in ways obvious to victims and the general public, such as the 2014 destructive malware attack on Sony Pictures and the worldwide WannaCry ransomware campaign in 2017.
“Since the beginning of reconciliation with the US in 2018, North Korean attacks in general have become more subtle and less obvious or ‘noisy’, suggesting greater efforts to avoid detection and attribution,” Prudhomme added.
But Mandiant’s Plan disagreed with this assessment.
“North Korean operators have significantly improved their TTPs [tactics, techniques, and procedures] over time, especially compared to their earliest identified incidents,” he said. “However, North Korean operations tend to demonstrate poor OPSEC and don’t put much focus on remaining undetected.”

"North Korea has conducted six nuclear tests, first in October 2006 and then in May 2009 under Kim Jong-il. Under Kim Jong-un’s leadership, the country detonated weapons in February 2013, January and September 2016, and September 2017." [1] Thus since their first test, they have detonated a nuclear weapon in the first year of both of Obama's terms and Trump's term. On a very small sample, this is a base rate of 100%. Kim Jong Un has presided over 114 missile tests in his nearly 10 years in power, avg. 11/year, though the rate has somewhat declined in 2017-2020. They are believed to have 5 missile types with a range above 10,000 km: the Hwasong 13, 14, and 15, the KN 14, and the Taepodong 2 [1]. The Hwasong 13 has never been tested, the 14 and 15 were tested three times in 2017 (Trump's first year in office), and the KN 14 and Taepodong 2 have no record of being tested [2]. Thus far in 2021, an unnamed short-range missile has been tested twice, most recently on 24 Mar. Thus NK has a history of 3 ICBM tests and 6 nuclear tests since 2006, and in Trump's first year in office, both ICBMs and nukes were detonated. US policy toward NK has been incoherent given the change of administration from Obama to Trump and now Biden. My expectation is Biden will return to a NK policy far more inline with Obama, though that may prove impossible given the intervening years. Kim will be unwilling to give up the increased legitimacy conferred on him by meeting directly with a sitting US president, with no concessions provided in return. I would like to know more about China's position toward NK, why certain ICBMs have never been tested, what motivated ICBM and nuclear tests in the past, whether those tests were preceded by other events, such as tests of short-range missiles. Inside (tech) view: North Korea had two missiles with a (presumptive) 10,000 km range, the Hwasong 14 and 15 - but neither has been tested at that range.    It unveiled a new missile in October 2020 that has not been tested, and in January 2021 it unveiled an SLB that has also not be tested.  We assume the new missiles have a range equal or greater than the Hwasong 14.  As Kogo noted, tests tend to cluster, so it seems plausible that the current cluster will be capped off by the launch of one of the new missiles.  His assessment of 30% seems reasonable.
Regarding nuclear tests,  the rate of 0.6 per year is correct, but in spite of breakdown in negotiations, there is not evidence I could find that North Korea has developed a larger yield nuclear device.  NK seems to be focusing more on delivery mechanisms than on larger yields, as the former is more a game-changer in terms of US perception of risk.  If NK conducts a test, I predict it will be a test of the miniaturized nuclear warhead that military intelligence believes they possess.  However, all tests to date have escalated in size.  A test of a smaller device would be technologically useful but symbolically less attractive, unless paired with test of a delivery mechanism.  So I judge the likelihood of a nuclear device alone to be lower than the likelihood of both.
